column1: Lucan ( LOO-kən; (Irish: "Leamhcán" meaning "Place of the Elms") is a suburban town and village located roughly 12km west of Dublin City Centre on the River Liffey. It is located near the Strawberry Beds and Lucan Weir
column2: and at the confluence of the River Griffeen. The majority of the area lies under the jurisdiction of South Dublin County Council while a small portion north of the River Liffey
column3: including Laraghcon
column5: St Catherine's Park and Lucan Demesne
column6: lies within the jurisdiction of Fingal County Council. Main road access to Lucan is from the N4
column7: and the M50 motorway at Junction 7.

column2: 'leamhachán' refers to the marsh-mallow plant
column3: used up to modern times in folk medicine (for sprains and chest infections) and sweet manufacture
column4: and so the name could be rendered as "place of marsh-mallow plants" or "land abounding in marsh-mallows."  The plant grows in the Liffey Valley and surrounds
column5: as recorded in the 1837 Ainmleabhar Paróiste
column7: the placename was described as meaning 'a marshy place'.

column1: There is evidence of prehistoric settlement in Lucan as the features that attracted early people such as river access
column2: fishing
column3: well-drained soil and hunting were all around. There is significant prehistoric activity in the Cooldrinagh townland of Lucan
column4: with early Mesolithic flints found in significant quantities
column5: as well as the remains of two small kerbed passage tombs. In the area around Vesey Park there are remains of a hillfort (Knockanardousk "hill of the high water") that may have been the house and enclosure of an early lord of Lucan in medieval times. This enclosure also contained a souterrain
column6: excavated in the 18th century by George Petrie and of which
column7: some of the finds are in the National Museum of Ireland.

column1: When Oliver Cromwell came to Ireland
column2: Lucan was a village of 120 inhabitants.
Sir William Sarsfield acquired Lucan Manor
column3: and the property became closely associated with the Sarsfield family. Patrick Sarsfield
column5: was born in the castle that had occupied the manor grounds and was granted the title Earl of Lucan by King James II.Lucan House was built on the site of Sarsfield's castle in 1772
column6: by the Rt Hon. Agmondisham Vesey
column7: who was descended from the Sarsfield family. The circular ground floor dining room is said to have been an inspiration for the Oval Office of the White House. The decorative plasterwork was carried out by Michael Stapleton. Over the years
column8: the house passed out of the Vesey family and
column10: has been the residence of the Italian ambassador to Ireland. In the grounds of the house is the spa
column11: the waters of which attracted people to the town in previous times.

column1: The influence of the Sarsfield and Vesey families on Lucan is still apparent in the area. For example
column2: the local Gaelic Athletic Association club is Lucan Sarsfields and a pub in the village bears the name 'The Vesey Arms'.

column1: The discovery of a sulphurous spa in Lucan in 1758 brought the district into prominence
column2: and it became a mecca for weekend parties from Dublin and the surrounding countryside. A ballroom was erected and subsequently a hotel.

column1: Most of the structures in Lucan village were constructed as part of a large redevelopment around 1815.  Later
column2: Lucan was a terminus on the combination of tram lines serving Lucan and Leixlip from Dublin city centre.

column1: Lucan village is located north of the N4/M4 national primary route to the west and northwest of Ireland. The village is approximately 5 km (3.1 mi) west of the M50 Dublin ring road. An outer-orbital distributor called the Outer Ring Road
column2: designated as R136
column3: from the N4 (Woodies) interchange to the N81 Tallaght Bypass

column1: Lucan is located between two major national/commuter railway lines. The original Lucan North (Leixlip) Station on the north/northwest line
column2: and Lucan South station on the south/southwest line
column3: were closed in 1941 and 1947
column4: respectively. The greenfield development of the Lucan townlands as a major residential area was predicated on the prime location between the motorways and railways. Adamstown railway station re-opened in 2007 to serve the area; it is located south of Finnstown
column5: Lucan. This station will also service significant further developments planned to the south of Adamstown townlands and the south/southwest commuter line.

column1: In 2018 it was announced that the Luas is planned to be extended to Lucan under the governments 'Project Ireland 2040' transport plan.

column1: Weston Airport is located to the west of Lucan near the Dublin/Kildare border. This facility conducts pilot training and serves privately owned light aircraft and helicopters. Its new terminal is located south of the M4 to the east of the Dublin Celbridge Road and Kildare border.
It is said that King John's bridge
column2: in Griffeen Park in Lucan
column3: is the oldest surviving bridge in Ireland.

column1: Lucan House is a seven-bay two-storey over basement Palladian country villa. Agmonisham Vesey cleared the previous residence and began construction in 1772. The architecture is the work of Vesey and William Chambers
column2: with Michael Stapleton responsible for the plasterwork. The estate passed through the Sarsfield
column3: Vesey and Colthurst families through marriage and also was once the resident of Charles Hugh O'Conor
column4: the third son of Charles Owen O'Conor and then
column6: it was purchased by the Italian Government for use as the residence of the Italian Ambassador to Ireland. The remainder of the estate land is now Liffey Valley Park.

column1: The Griffeen Valley Park runs along the Griffeen River
column2: with some smaller outlying park areas among housing developments to the west. The main area of the park is split by the Lucan Bypass
column3: with Vesey Park on one side and Griffeen Park on the other. The most important feature of the Griffeen Valley Park is the old woodland in Vesey Park that was retained when the park was formed. This woodland is most extensive along the Griffeen River and contains mature deciduous and coniferous trees. The most important area on the river is the wet woodland containing the most extensive fern and bryophyte growth recorded in the five parks surveyed. The woodland also provides the habitat for the protected species Hypericum hirsutum.

column1: Lucan has three GAA teams. Lucan Sarsfields
column2: the largest sports organisation in the town
column3: was founded in 1886 and is located on the 12th Lock on the Grand Canal. Lucan Sarsfields won the u/21 Dublin Football Championship and a Minor double of Football and Hurling in 2005. Lucan Sarsfields U21 B team won the Callum Sally Cup in 2005 and again in 2009. The Dublin Hurling captain
column5: plays for Sarsfields. Westmanstown Gaels are also located in north Lucan at the Westmanstown Sports Centre
column6: which has diversified from its roots as a leisure centre for the Garda Siochana.

column1: Esker Amateur Boxing Club hosted the first ever All-Female Amateur Boxing tournament in Ireland during November and December 2013. It has grown to become the World's largest female-only boxing tournament in 2019 with 19 countries spread over 3 continents attending. Esker Boxing Club have been running a long campaign to build their own permanent clubhouse. They are the largest sports club in Lucan without permanent facilities to work from.In January 2008
column2: Lucan Boxing Club reformed after a few years hiatus. In its first season back
column3: the club won the Dublin Junior Club of the Year (2008/2009 season).

column1: The two main golf courses in Lucan are Lucan Golf Club and Hermitage Golf Club. Both courses are member-run and date back over a hundred years.
Liffey Valley Par 3 is a par 3 golf course that is situated between Leixlip and Lucan.
Liffey Celtics Basketball Club is a basketball club for girls aged from 7 up to senior
column2: and boys aged 7 to senior. There are 13 (9 girls & 10 boys) underage basketball teams competing in the Dublin Area Board League and Cup competitions. Training and home matches take place at the Colaiste Cois Life (Lucan)
column3: Leixlip Amenities Centre
column4: and Confey GAA (Leixlip). The club has a senior women's team competing in the Basketball Ireland Super League.
